Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research investigates a new understanding of how feelings regulate thinking. The proposed experiments vary people's mindsets and their moods to assess a new explanation for several different textbook phenomena concerning emotion and thought. The theory is that the moment-to-moment flashes of affect that people regularly experience have the effect of tuning their thought processes to help negotiate everyday cognitive tasks. This process occurs when feelings signal the value of a person's current mindset for a given task. Affect thus acts like a mental traffic cop; positive affect giving a green light and negative affect a red light to one's currently active mindset.

Thirty years of research has assumed that specific affective states automatically activate specific cognitive orientations. Thus, textbooks say that happy moods increase big picture thinking and creativity, but also increase stereotyping and false memories. In addition, they say that sad moods can increase accuracy, systematic processing, and "depressive realism." In contrast, a new view of these phenomena has very different implications for how people's emotional reactions regulate thinking and problem solving. The proposed research tests this new view by specifying conditions capable of both replicating and reversing the predictions made by the standard view.

Broader impacts include the research training of graduate and undergraduate students, who will participate in all aspects of the project from planning to conducting the research and from analyzing the data to its publication. The importance of this new view is that a large body of findings previously assumed to reflect basic and general principles may actually be situationally specific in nature. Social psychologists have learned previously that principles from research on primarily male respondents are less general than first assumed. Similarly, conclusions from primarily Western samples have led to culturally specific, rather than thoroughly general, facts about human nature. In a related way, the proposed view implies that the results of past research on emotional influences on cognition reveal as much about the normative situations that were studied as they do about how emotion actually influences thought. The proposed principles promise a more generally applicable answer to questions about mind and emotion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We examined how emotional feelings regulate people’s thinking and evaluative judgments. Experiments induced mild mood states by having people write about happy or sad life experiences in order to generate affective reactions to observe affective influences on problem solving and evaluative judgments. The project produced two potentially important discoveries.

One discovery is that the flashes of affect that people regularly experience regulate their thought processes to help them negotiate everyday cognitive tasks. This process occurs when affect signals the value of one’s current mindset for a given task. Affect thus acts like a mental traffic light, positive affect giving a green light and negative affect a red light to regulate whether to employ one’s current mindset or not. This discovery is important, because in thirty years of prior research, we and other investigators had assumed that feeling happy triggered a specific kinds of thought – creative, big picture thinking -- and that feelings sad or other negative emotions produced a detailed, local focus. That generalization is still more or less accurate, but not for the reasons usually assumed. 

Rather than a fixed link between feelings and thinking styles, the connection turns out to be malleable. The reason that feeling happy typically triggers a big picture focus is that people generally adopt a moderately global focus in most situations anyway. Happy affect then says “go” to that inclination and sad affect says “stop.” As a result, happy moods tend to generate big picture thinking and sad moods tend to generate a detailed focus. We discovered this process by varying the default orientation that people had. We found that positive affect will enhance whatever orientation is already most accessible. When a global mode of thought is dominant, positive affect will produce more of that, but when a detailed mode of thought is more accessible, positive affect will produce more of that. Thus, there is no fixed linkage between feelings and thinking.

Indeed, the whole point of such affective feedback is to nudge us toward whatever mode of thought is appropriate to a given situation. To be adaptive, the impact of affect must be highly context sensitive, not fixed and immutable. Thus, we found that many laboratory phenomenon showing affective influences on thought could be reversed simply by changing what orientation was most accessible for affect to regulate. The exciting idea is that our everyday affective reactions (which are ever present) steer our thoughts by providing feedback about their likely value in the current situation. The insight is that emotional feelings are not just about things in the world like William James’ bear in the woods, they are also about our own interior thoughts.

A second direction of this project based on this initial discovery concerned people’s evaluative judgments. We found that instead of the usual “rose-colored glasses” effect in which positive affect makes everything look rosier, under certain conditions positive affect leads to more negative rather than more positive judgments. Again, the key, we believe, is that affect provides information – not only about the objects of judgments themselves – but sometimes about one’s thoughts and provisional opinions about such objects. An implication of that fact is that feeling happy should make people evaluate disliked things more negatively and liked things more positively. Positive affect should thus embolden one’s existing thoughts, producing in some cases, not more positive, but more negative judgments. In other words, positive affect, rather than indicating that the external object of judgment is good, indicates that one’s internal reaction to the object is good.

In the final year of the project, we asked how general these processes are. We analyzed several Big Data sets to see whether positive affect produced more favorable ratings and attitudes or, as our data implied, more extreme ratings and attitudes. In each dataset, we found more evidence for extremity effects, indicating that our lab findings reflected a quite general pattern.

The processes we study are basic, universal, and frequently misunderstood. As our work continues to refine the discoveries we have made, it is possible that there will be therapeutic and other benefits. For example, the realization that one’s own thoughts can be the object of one’s affect has potential implications for a kind of affective judo therapy in which one tries to leverage against their own thoughts the negative affect of anxious and depressed persons. If successful, their negative affect would be experienced as saying “stop,” to their destructive and maladaptive thoughts and inclinations. In any case, the initial findings from this research promise a more generally applicable answer to such questions about mind and emotion
